inlineContent.text: This class is rarely used directly in D-Bus clients. If you are writing
a D-Bus client, it is often easier to use the
or
APIs.
As an exception to the usual GLib rule that a particular object must not
be used by two threads at the same time,
â€™s methods may be
called from any thread. This is so that
and
can safely return the same
when called from any thread.
Most of the ways to obtain a
automatically initialize it
(i.e. connect to D-Bus): for instance,
and
, and the synchronous versions of those methods, give you an
initialized connection. Language bindings for GIO should use
or
, which also initialize the
connection.
If you construct an uninitialized
, such as via
, you must initialize it via
or
before using its methods or properties.
Calling methods or accessing properties on a
that has not
completed initialization successfully is considered to be invalid, and leads
to undefined behaviour. In particular, if initialization fails with a
[GLibError](//documentation/glib/gliberror, the only valid thing you can do with that
is to
free it with

instance.

as a strong reference or owner of a

GIOStream represents an object that has both read and write streams.
Generally the two streams act as separate input and output streams,
but they share some common resources and state. For instance, for
seekable streams, both streams may use the same position.
